landing.h2: Welcome to the iSCAPE Citizen Kit!
landing.h4: Let’s get you set up with a Smart Citizen Kit, and sensing in no time!

smart_citizen.h2: Smart Citizen is a movement for civic participation in a modern world
smart_citizen.h4: Smart Citizen creates open tools for citizens to be better informed about the world around them.

smart_citizen_brief.h4: This sensor is a Smart Citizen Kit for environmental sensing. It measures sound, air quality, humidity, and lots of other things

smart_citizen_brief2.h4: The kit sends all the measurements to the Smart Citizen website. It's open and free for all to see, question and play with...

whats_in_the_box.h4: There's a few pieces we need to set up the Kit, let's check we have them all

selectparts.h2: Click on all the things you have received
selectparts.h4: We need to know this to make the set up work smoothly
selectparts.part1_desc: This is where all the sensors are. It connects to the bigger, hardware board, so that the sensors can transmit what they find.
selectparts.part2_desc: This is where all the computation takes place. Anytime you want to connect something to the Smart Citizen, it will be on this board
selectparts.part3_desc: This powers the device. Every so often it has to be recharged, especially after long periods of continuous use.
selectparts.part4_desc: The Particles Sensor helps to get better data regarding particules in the air.

selectparts2.h4: You don’t have to have the case, but it does protect your kit against the elements
selectparts2.part5_desc: The case is water resistant and allows the device to be affixed to a variety of surfaces.
selectparts2.part6_desc: Placed between the hardware board and sensor board, this keeps the boards study.
selectparts2.part7_desc: Closing the case, this is used dto protect the device from rain. Make sure to place the holes over the sound sensor.
selectparts2.part8_desc: This is used to fasten the case to the cover.

confirm_parts.h4: Now let's put it all together

kitbuild1.text: Place a spacer in the holes on the sensor board

kitbuild2.text: Connect the pins on the sensor board to the hardware board

kitbuild3.text: Connect the battery to the hardware board

kitbuild4.h2: And finally, turn on the Kit
kitbuild4.text: Push the button on the Kit multiple times, until the LED is red.

case1.h2: Next, we'll place it all in the casing
case1.text: Make sure you place it with the battery cable towards the bottom of the casing

case2.h2: ... and to finish, seal the cover
case2.text: Place the transparent plastic on the front of the case and fix it in place with the two white plugs.

choose_connection.h2: How do you want to connect your kit to the internet?

wifi_enter.h2: What network are we connecting it to?
wifi_enter.h4: We have to type it in manually...
wifi_enter.input1_error: A name is required to connect to a network

handshake.h4: Hold up your kit and press it on the screen over the box below and press 'connect'. Make sure the blue side of the kit is facing you

wifi_check.h4: It seems there is a problem. Notice that the Kit light is red, please retry the Wi-Fi name and password
wifi_check.input1_error: A name is required to connect to a network

accesspoint_pre.h1: LET'S TRY WITH A PHONE OR TABLET INSTEAD
accesspoint_pre.h4: This approach is more reliable. You will need a phone or tablet.

accesspoint_1.h2: On your mobile device, go to your Wi-Fi settings and connect to the Wi-Fi called:
accesspoint_1.h3_2: of the Kit, located in the
accesspoint_1.h4: If you do not see it, make sure your kit is powered on with a red LED.

accesspoint_2.h2: You should see this window on your mobile device
accesspoint_2.h3_1: If that did not happen, open the browser on your device and go to

ap_final.h2: When asked for your onboarding token submit the following. Then Select your Wi-Fi from the list, and enter the password.
ap_final.h4: If the submitted wifi and password are correct you will be redirected shortly, follow the instructions on www.MySCK.me

offline_pre.h1: LET'S TRY WITH A mobile and a SD Card
offline_pre.h4: This approach is pretty reliable. You will need a smartphone and a sd-card

offline_1.h2: On your mobile device, go to your Wi-Fi settings and connect to the Wi-Fi called:
offline_1.h3_2: of the Kit, located in the
offline_1.h4: If you do not see it, make sure your kit is powered on with a red LED.

offline_2.h2: You should see this window on your mobile device. Click on the SD Card mode link
offline_2.h3_1: If that did not happen, open the browser on your device and go to
offline_2.h4: If it does not work, make sure you are connected to the wifi

offline_3.h2: FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS AND CLICK THE START LOGGING BUTTON
offline_3.h4: Right after you do this, you should be able to see your kits LED slowly fading in pink. If the LED is blinking fast, there have been an error.

sensorName_prep.h1: LET'S GIVE YOUR SENSOR AN IDENTITY
sensorName_prep.h4: This will help us know where this data is coming from...

sensorName.h2: What shall we name the sensor?
sensorName.h4: You can name it pretty much anything. This is how it will appear on the Smart Citizen map.

location_prep.h2: Where will you install the sensor?
location_prep.h4: By pressing 'allow' on the pop up we can determine the current location of the sensor. You can manually adjust this later to anywhere you want to place the sensor.

location_map.h2: If you want to adjust it or pin it elsewhere, you can do that here
location_map.h4: Remember wherever your device goes, it will need wi-fi. Otherwise you'll have to go get it every now and again and connect it to your computer to sync the data

location_tags.h2: Is there anything we should know about location?
location_tags.h4: Selecting from the tags below can help us make sense of the data, and compare it more accurately

confirm_location.h4: Finally, let's save all this work we've done.

account1.h2: We can save the Kit with your email address
account1.h4: If you already have an account, we'll add it to that. If not, we'll quickly make a new one

login.h2b: enter your password below to finish!
login.h4: This will push all of your new Kit's data to your account

account2.h2: Nice, so you're new to Smart Citizen?
account2.h4: Add a username to your profile, so users know who owns the sensor.

account3.h2: Now, filly a password to secure everything
account3.h4a: the password has to be at least 8 characters long
account3.h4b: And one more time to make sure there are no mistakes
account3.input1_error: The password must be at least 8 characters long

final.h2: You have successfully installed and connected the Smart Citizen Kit to the internet, and then added the kit to the global community of sensors
final.h4: Visit SmartCitizen.me to see your Kit in action capturing data. Don't forget to read the manual for assembly instructions and good tips on placing your sensor in the wild
